coredata.dc:description: The lithium-sulfur battery is an attractive energy-storage device with low cost and high energy density. However, its development is still restricted by “shuttle effect”, lithium dendrite growth and safety problem. Herein, a novel PEO-PAN-LLZO composite gel polymer electrolyte (CGPE) was designed to overcome these issues. A porous composite membrane with excellent mechanical and interfacial properties was formed after casting dispersion of PAN, PEO, LLZO sheets, which can effectively absorb electrolyte, inhibit “shuttle effect” and protect lithium anode. A conductive acetylene black layer was coated on the membrane to further hinder the migration and enhance the redox kinetics of polysulfides. The CGPE based lithium-sulfur battery displays remarkably high specific capacities (1459 and 942 mAh/g at 0.1 and 1C respectively) and outstanding cycling performance (555 mAh/g at 1C after 500 cycles, average decay/cycle of 0.082%). The unique CGPE is promising for the practical application of high-performance lithium-sulfur battery.

head.ce:title: Rationally designing composite gel polymer electrolyte enables high sulfur utilization and stable lithium anode

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The lithium-sulfur battery is an attractive energy-storage device with low cost and high energy density. However, its development is still restricted by “shuttle effect”, lithium dendrite growth and safety problem. Herein, a novel PEO-PAN-LLZO composite gel polymer electrolyte (CGPE) was designed to overcome these issues. A porous composite membrane with excellent mechanical and interfacial properties was formed after casting dispersion of PAN, PEO, LLZO sheets, which can effectively absorb electrolyte, inhibit “shuttle effect” and protect lithium anode. A conductive acetylene black layer was coated on the membrane to further hinder the migration and enhance the redox kinetics of polysulfides. The CGPE based lithium-sulfur battery displays remarkably high specific capacities (1459 and 942 mAh/g at 0.1 and 1C respectively) and outstanding cycling performance (555 mAh/g at 1C after 500 cycles, average decay/cycle of 0.082%). The unique CGPE is promising for the practical application of high-performance lithium-sulfur battery.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: The lithium-ion battery has dominated the main market of the new energy vehicles because of the environmental issues from the fossil energy. However, the energy density and security are far from sufficient to meet the growing demand [1–3]. The lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery has been attracting extensive attention for the high theoretical specific capacity and inexpensiveness [4,5], while some key challenges have seriously hindered their wide commercialization, including the inherent low sulfur conductivity, the lithium polysulfide shuttle effect, the adverse reactions of the lithium anode and electrolyte, etc [6–9]. Various strategies have been proposed by scientists to overcome these drawbacks by designing materials with good conductivity or strong chemical affinity to prepare highly conductive sulfur composite cathode [10–12], adding additives to the liquid-state electrolytes [13–17], protecting the surface of lithium anodes [18,19], modification of the separators [20,21], and applying solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) [22,23]. The SSEs possess high safety and excellent mechanical properties, which are beneficial to suppress the dendrite growth and reduce the “shuttle effect” in the traditional liquid-state electrolytes [24]. However, the imperfect ionic conductivity for the solid-state electrolyte and the low wettability of electrode/electrolyte interface limit their wide applications in Li-S batteries [25].

The gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), combining advantages of liquid-state and solid-state electrolytes, exhibit good interface wettability and high ion-conductivity in additional to high safety and mechanical properties [26]. The common polymers such as Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [27,28], Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) [29–31], Polyacrylonitrile (PAN) [9,30], and Polyethylene oxide (PEO) [28,32] have been used as the matrix of GPEs. As a polymer matrix of GPEs, PEO displays high chemical stability, high cathode compatibility, low price and excellent processability, and holds potential for application in the field of GPEs. However, the low ionic conductivity of PEO (10-7 ∼ 10-5 S cm−1) limits its wide application [28,32]. PAN, another typical polymer matrix, possesses high thermal stability and ionic conductivity at room temperature (∼10-3 S cm−1), however, the strong polar CN groups in PAN are apt to react with the lithium anode, causing the poor interface stability [33,34]. The polymer/polymer hybridization can effectively combine the advantages of both polymers to improve the properties of the gel polymer electrolytes. In addition, the addition of inorganic materials (such as LLTO [35], LATP [36], LLZO [37], etc.) to the polymer can decrease the crystallinity and inhibit the passivation effect with lithium anode to some extent [9]. Moreover, a porous carbon layer covered on the gel polymer electrolyte can provide plenty of pores to effectively adsorb lithium polysulfides, thus inhibiting their diffusion to the lithium anode [29].

Herein, a new type of acetylene black coated PEO-PAN-Li7La3Zr2O12 composite gel polymer electrolyte was designed, to inhibit the “shuttle effect”, increase the utilization of elemental sulfur, and improve the long-term cycling and rate capability the Li-S battery. Firstly, the cellulose nonwoven fabric serves as the supporting template for the GPE, which can effectively improve the mechanical property of the PEO-PAN- Li7La3Zr2O12 composite [38]. Secondly, the composite of PAN and PEO can not only inherit the good mechanical properties of PEO and excellent ionic conductivity of PAN, but also form the chemical bond between the hydroxyl groups in PEO and the CN groups in PAN, to reduce the adverse reaction between CN groups and lithium anode, increase the GPE/lithium interface stability and promote lithium-ion diffusion [39]. Thirdly, LLZO sheets possess high intrinsic ionic conductivity and strong chemical affinity for soluble lithium polysulfides, which are conducive to accelerate the diffusion of Li+ and inhibit the “shuttle effect”, thus increasing the Li-S battery performance. Finally, the acetylene black coating can act as an excellent electronic conductor and a physical barrier, which can enhance the redox kinetics and hinder the polysulfide diffusion. The Li-S cell using PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE displays a remarkable cyclic performance with only a 0.082 % decay/cycle over 500 cycles (1C), indicating that the designed CGPE is promising for wide application in the high-performance Li-S battery.

Garnet type Li7La3Zr2O12 sheets were synthesized using a sol–gel process [37]. LiNO3, ZrO(NO3)2 and La(NO3)3 were dissolved in distilled water, following with the addition of sucrose and stirring for 1 h. The solution was then heated for 12 h with stirring at 80 °C, dried and annealed for 3 h at 250 °C and 1 h at 850 °C (or 750 °C), to obtain LLZO sheets (or LLZO blocks).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fabrication of the composite gel polymer electrolyte (CGPE)
ce:section.ce:para: Polyethylene oxide (PEO, AR, Mw = 600000), Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, AR, Mw = 600000) and the LLZO sheets (1: 1: 2) were added into N,N-dimethyl formamide (DMF) and stirred to obtain a homogeneous dispersion at 60 °C. Acetylene black (AB, AR, Aladdin) and Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF, AR, Arkema) (4:1) were added to N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP, AR, Aladdin) and stirred at 60 °C overnight to get a uniform AB-PVDF dispersion. The PEO-PAN-LLZO dispersion was casted on one side of the cellulose nonwoven fabric, and the AB-PVDF dispersion was coated on the other side, and then dried at 60 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. After that, disks of 19 mm were cut from the membrane and immersed in the commercial liquid electrolyte (1.0 wt% LiNO3, 1 M LiTFSI DME/DOL (1:1)) for about 1 h to get the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE for using in the 2032-type coin cells. In addition, the CGPEs with different LLZO loading rates and different LLZO particle sizes were fabricated using the same procedure, namely, PEO-PAN CGPE (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 0), PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1 (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 1), PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO blocks is 1: 1: 2) and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 3), respectively.

Morphologies of membranes were observed with a scanning electron microscope (SEM, XL30TMP, Netherlands), and the cross-section analysis was performed after quenched in the liquid nitrogen. The electronic universal testing machine (EZ-LX, Japan) was used to test the mechanical properties of CGPE. The Xpert Pro MPD diffractometer was used to perform X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis on materials. The liquid absorption rate of the membranes was obtained by calculating the difference in quality before and after immersion in the electrolyte for 1 h. Stoichiometric amounts of elemental sulfur and lithium sulfide (Li2S) were mixed in the solvent of 1, 3 dioxolane and ethylene glycol dimethyl ether (1:1), stirring with heating to get a Li2S8 solution in glove box [29]. 20 mL DME/DOL (1:1) solution was put into one side of an H-type cell, 20 mL Li2S8 solution was put into the other side, and the membrane was sandwiched in the middle, sealed in a glove box before test. The membranes were also added to 2 mL Li2S8 solution and sealed for the measurement of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250xi).

Symmetric cells were fabricated by sandwiching the prepared membranes between two stainless steel blocking electrodes for measurement of the ionic conductivity (Biologic VMP3 electrochemical station) with 10 mV perturbation and frequency from 1 MHz to 10 mHz. Li/membrane/Li symmetrical cells were fabricated to measure the interfacial resistance after storage at 25 °C.

A Li/membrane/Li symmetric cell was also assembled to measure the transference number of lithium ion (t Li+) with the potentiostatic polarization method at room temperature, according to the formula (2) given below:

. Linear Sweep Voltammetry (1.0–6.0 V, 0.1 mV s−1) was used to test the electrochemical stability windows of membranes [39].

KB/S composite material was prepared by the melt-diffusion process for 12 h at 155 °C (mass ratio 1: 4). KB@S, PVDF and Super P (80: 10: 10) were mixed and stirred in NMP to get a uniform slurry, which was then coated on Al film and dried before punching into cathode disks of 14 mm (S loading: 1.0–1.5 mg cm−2). Finally, the 2032-type coin cells were fabricated (the sulfur to electrolyte ratio (S/E) was controlled at about 0.06 mg μL−1), and cyclic voltammetry (Biologic VMP3), rate and cyclic capabilities (NEWARE BTS) of the cells were measured from 1.7 to 2.8 V.

Fig. 1 a depicts the preparation of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE. As illustrated Fig. 1a, after casting the homogeneous PEO-PAN-LLZO dispersion on one side of the cellulose nonwoven fabric, the other side was coated with the AB-PVDF dispersion to form a uniform coating with the adhesive effect of PVDF. Fig. S1a and b show the typical SEM images of the prepared LLZO with the sheet-like structure. The lateral sizes of the LLZO sheets are in the range of 2–15 μm, and the thicknesses are around several hundred nanometers. Fig. S1c displays the typical surface SEM image of the cellulose nonwoven fabric. The cellulose nonwoven fabric consists of interwoven micro-fibers and displays a porous structure. The cross-section and surface morphologies of the as-prepared PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE were shown in Fig. 1b-d. Two layers are clearly observed from the cross-section of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE (Fig. 1b). The AB coating is about 10.2 um and the corresponding surface is shown in Fig. 1c. Plenty of micropores can be observed on AB coating surface, which are beneficial for physical absorption of electrolyte and polysulfides, to promote the Li+ transport and inhibit the “shuttle effect”. The AB coating also possesses high electric conductivity, which may significantly increase the transfer of charge during the redox reactions. The other layer (about 49.1 um) corresponds to the PEO-PAN-LLZO composite layer (Fig. 1d) composed of cellulose nonwoven fabric, PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets, which respectively served as the supporting framework and the organic–inorganic polymer hybrid components. Fig. 1d demonstrates that the PEO and PAN are well bonded with the LLZO sheets, resulting in the uniform dispersion of LLZO sheets in the polymer matrix and the formation of porous structure, which can improve the utilization of LLZO sheets and the liquid absorbability of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE. The uniformly dispersed LLZO sheets and porous structure may provide abundant transport channels for promoting the Li+ diffusion in CGPE [29,31]. Fig. S1d-f display the surface and cross-section SEM images of as-prepared PEO-PAN CGPE. Compared to PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, the PEO-PAN GPE is composited of two layers, including an AB coating (about 10.3 um) and a PEO-PAN composite layer (about 49.7 um) composed of cellulose nonwoven fabric, PEO and PAN. The PEO-PAN composite layer exhibits fewer microporous structure, which may lead to the poor liquid absorbability [32].

XRD was performed to explore the interaction between PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets. As shown in Fig. S2, the LLZO sheets crystallizes well and can be assigned to the cubic phase (JCPDS No. 80–0457) [40]. Both PEO and PAN possess high crystallinity, while the diffraction peaks at 15-20° and 22-26° of the PEO-PAN composite become wider and weaker, indicating the decrease in polymer crystallinity, which can be ascribed to the increase of amorphous region after combination [41]. After adding the LLZO sheets, the PEO-PAN-LLZO exhibits even wider and weaker diffraction peaks between 15 and 26° compared to PEO-PAN, demonstrating the further reduced crystallinity of the PEO-PAN composites after adding LLZO sheets, probably due to the fact that the addition of LLZO sheets can destroy the ordered arrangement of both PEO and PAN segments and increase the proportion of amorphous regions [42]. The increase of the polymer amorphous regions is beneficial to the Li+ migration [23,34]. In addition, all diffraction peaks belonging to LLZO sheets can be observed in PEO-PAN-LLZO, indicating that the well crystal structure and high ionic conductivity of LLZO sheets remain during the formation of the composite gel polymer electrolyte. The increase of the amorphous regions and the introduction of the conductive LLZO sheets can significantly increase the ionic conductivity of the PEO-PAN-LLZO composite.

Excellent mechanical properties of GPEs are important for their practical applications in Li-S batteries. The stress–strain curves of PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE under dry membrane conditions are shown in Fig. 2 a. The cellulose nonwoven fabric in the CGPEs is used as the substrate and the PEO also possesses good mechanical property. As displayed in Fig. 2a, the maximum stress that the PEO-PAN CGPE can withstand is about 5.40 MPa, corresponding to the strain of about 5.78 %. While the maximum tensile strength that the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE can bear increases to 10.64 MPa, and the corresponding strain decreases to 4.01 %. These results may be ascribed to the LLZO sheets embedded in the polymer matrix, which can absorb most of the deformation energy generated from the external forces, and hinder the sliding of grain boundary and improve the mechanical strength of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE [36,39]. The excellent mechanical strength enables the GPEs to remain mechanically intact during the accidental collision and compression, and provide the great commercial potential in rechargeable batteries.

The TG curves of the Celgard membrane, PEO, PAN, PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE were shown in Fig. 2b, the weight of the Celgard membrane begins to decrease at about 260 °C, which can be due to the decomposition reaction of polyethylene. While the PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE are 180 °C and 300 °C respectively, indicating the better thermal stability of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE than PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane, which can be attributed to the addition of LLZO sheets with excellent thermal stability and the formed organic–inorganic composite with more stable structure [21,37]. To explore the stability of membranes at high temperature, the Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE were maintained for 1 h at 150 °C, and digital photos before and after heating were taken and shown in respectively Fig. 2c and d. It is evidently that the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE possesses the smallest thermal shrinkage rate i.e. almost no obvious shrinkage, indicating the best structural stability at high temperature [37]. The excellent structural stability of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE is essential to meet the high working temperature requirements of Li-S batteries operated under extreme conditions.

Fig. 3 a and Fig. S3 respectively show the ion-conductivity versus inverse temperature and the EIS profiles of Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE within 20–70 °C. The ion-conductivity of all membranes increases with the increase of temperature, resulted from the increased movement of the free Li+ and polymer chain [43]. Ionic conductivities of the Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN GPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE at 30 °C are respectively calculated to be 0.79 × 10-3, 0.98 × 10-3 and 2.01 × 10-3 S cm−1. Notably, PEO-PAN CGPE possesses higher ionic conductivity than Celgard membrane, probably attributed to the improved electrolyte uptake and ionic transport from the porous PEO-PAN composite and AB coating, and the high intrinsic ionic conductivity of the PAN component [9,30]. Compared to PEO-PAN CGPE, the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE exhibits even higher ionic conductivity, which can be ascribed to the high ionic conductivity of LLZO sheets, and the synergistic effects of PAN, PEO and acetylene black [29].

The ionic conductivities of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE with different LLZO loading rates and different LLZO particle sizes were also tested, and the results are shown in Fig. S4 and Fig. S5. Fig. S4a and b display the EIS curves of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1 and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 at 30, 50 and 70 °C, respectively. Fig. S4c compares the conductivities of CGPEs with different contents of LLZO sheets, namely, PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1 (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 1), PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 2)，and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 3). As shown in Fig. S4c, the ion-conductivity of all CGPEs increases with the increase of temperature, resulted from the increased movement of free Li+ and polymer chain. Ionic conductivities of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1, PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 at 30 °C are respectively calculated to be 1.32 × 10-3, 2.01 × 10-3 and 1.18 × 10-3 S cm−1. With the increase of LLZO ratio (PEO: PAN: LLZO from 1: 1: 1 to 1: 1: 2 then to 1: 1: 3), the ionic conductivity of the CGPEs firstly increases and then decreases, probably ascribed to the gradual change of Li+ conduction mode from “polymer-rich phase” to “ceramic-rich phase” of the CGPE. In the “polymer-rich phase” structure, the polymer dominates the Li+ transport, which passes mainly through the polymer phase and the polymer/ceramic phase interface. When the LLZO ratio increases, the Li+ transport through the LLZO sheets may contribute effectively to increase the conductivity of CGPE. When the ceramic ratio is too high, the polymer might be difficult to fully fill the gap and effectively bridge between LLZO sheets, resulting in voids in the CGPE and which reduces the ionic conductivity of CGPE [44].

Fig. S5a displays the EIS curves of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 at 30, 50 and 70 °C, respectively, and Fig. S5b compares the conductivities of CGPEs with different LLZO particle sizes, namely, PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO sheets is 1: 1: 2) and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 (ratio of PEO, PAN and LLZO blocks is 1: 1: 2). Compared to PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 with LLZO blocks, the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE with LLZO sheets shows higher ion-conductivities under different temperatures. For example, the ion-conductivity of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 is 1.09 × 10-3 S cm−1 at 30 °C, much lower than that of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE (2.01 × 10-3 S cm−1), probably due to the small size and high surface area of LLZO sheet, which provides higher interfacial contact between LLZO and polymer and greatly increases the transport channels and conductivity of lithium ions [45]. The SEM images of LLZO blocks are shown in Fig. S5c and d. The obtained LLZO blocks are composed of irregular particles with size of about 4–10 μm, and the corresponding specific surface area is far less than that of LLZO sheets.

The SS/membranes/Li cells were fabricated to investigate the electrochemical stability of membranes and Fig. 3b shows the associated LSV curves. The sudden current change of the SS/Celgard membrane/Li and SS/PEO-PAN CGPE/Li cells occurs at respectively 4.50 and 4.75 V (vs Li/Li+), which can be indicating the decomposition of electrolyte at this voltage [26]. In contrast, the LSV curve for the SS/PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE/Li cell remains stable until 5.05 V and shows a slight upward trend afterwards, implying the oxidation reaction of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE beyond 5.05 V. These results demonstrate the wide electrochemical stability window and feasibility of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE for Li-S batteries.

Migration rate of lithium ions during charge/discharge processes greatly affects the battery polarization, and Li+ transference number (t Li+) of membranes is considered as an important factor for the power densities. Fig. 3c and Fig. S6 show the current–time curves of the Li/membranes/Li cells. The inset corresponds to the EIS curves before and after the polarization. The t Li+ of the membranes were calculated by formula (2) with a symmetric Li/membranes/Li cell and Table S1 summarizes the corresponding results. The interfacial resistance of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE increases from 23 to 31 Ω after polarization and the current decreases from 240.08 µA to 132.61 µA. According to formula (2), the calculated t Li+ for the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE is 0.42, while the values for the Celgard membrane and PEO-PAN CGPE are 0.22 and 0.29, respectively. The significantly increased t Li+ of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE may be mainly attributed to the addition of LLZO sheets with high intrinsic ionic conductivity and the abundant porous structure offerd by the PEO-PAN-LLZO composite and the AB coating. After the addition of the LLZO inorganic fillers, the interaction between the fillers and polymer chains may lead to the relax of the local chains and the promotion of the polymer segment movement, which notably increase the lithium-ion mobility inside the gel polymer electrolyte [9]. Therefore, the combination of the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite layer and the porous AB coating can provide abundant ways for the fast Li+ migration [46]. The electrochemical stability window and ionic conductivity of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE are also superior to that of the recently reported typical GPEs in the literature, as shown in Table S2.

The Li/membranes/Li cells were fabricated to evaluate the interface stability between lithium metal and membranes. Fig. 3d displays the membrane interfacial resistance (R i) variation with time at room temperature. Compared to the Celgard membrane and PEO-PAN CGPE, the R i values of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE are the lowest at different storage stages, indicating the addition of LLZO sheets and the AB coating can remarkably decrease the R i value. R i value of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE remains stable at around 23 Ω after 5 days, while that of the Celgard membrane and PEO-PAN CGPE still increases with the storage time. The stable R i value indicates the good interfacial stability between the membrans and lithium metal, which might be ascribed to the effective adsorbion of the solvents or impurities within the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite and the AB coating, thus protecting the lithium metal anode from undesirable side reactions [21].

To study the Li storage peformance of the Li-S cells, the coin cells with the Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE were assembled and the corresponding CV tests were carried out. Fig. 4 a, Fig. S7a and Fig. S7c show the CV curves of the cells at 0.1 mV s−1 between 1.7 and 2.8 V. During the multi-step scannings, the sulfur cathode exhibits typical reduction/oxidation peaks. For PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell, the reduction peaks at 2.00 and 2.30 V respectively correspond to the conversion from sulfur to polysulfides (Li2Sn, 4 < n < 8) and from polysulfides to t sulfides (Li2S2/Li2S). The oxidation peak (2.35 V) corresponds to the conversions of Li2S2/Li2S to elemental sulfur [12,13]. Compared to that of the cells assembled with the Celgard membrane (Fig. S7c) and the PEO-PAN CGPE (Fig. S7a), the CV curve of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE exhibits sharper and higher reduction and oxidation peaks, indicating the faster redox conversion between sulfur and lithium polysulfides, thus significantly inhibiting the shuttle effect and increasing the material utilization [27,47].
Δ V
of the PEO-PAN-LLZO cells is about 0.34 V, which is smaller than the cells with PEO-PAN CGPE (0.43 V) and Celgard membrane (0.44 V), and the lowest polarization of the PEO-PAN-LLZO cell may be ascribed to the high conductivity of the AB coating as well as the incorporated LLZO sheets.

Fig. 4b, Fig. S7b and Fig. S7d respectively display the CV curves of Li-S cells with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane at 0.1, 0.2 and 0.5 mV s−1. With the scanning rate increasing, reduction peaks of the cells with the PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane seriously deform, which may be due to the large polarization. In contrast, the CV curves of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell maintain similar shape from 0.1 to 0.5 mV s−1, which is originated from the increased lithium-ion diffusion and electron transfer and the reduced battery polarization from the addition of LLZO sheets and AB coating [29,37].

The rate performance of cells assembled using the Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE are shown in Fig. 4c. The Celgard membrane cell exhibits the discharge specific capacities of 988, 921, 810, 683, 245 and 1 mAh/g at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 3C (1C = 1675 mAh/g), and the PEO-PAN CGPE cell displays slightly increased discharge specific capacities of respectively 1137, 1033, 878, 758, 532 and 332 mAh/g from 0.1 to 3C, probably ascribed to the introduction of the conductive AB coating. The cell assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE displays the highest discharge specific capacities of respectively 1459, 1164, 1022, 883, 838 and 764 mAh/g from 0.1 to 3C. The excellent specific capacity and rate capability of PEO-PAN-LLZO cell are ascribed to the synergistic effects between the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite and the porous conductive AB coating, which can increase the lithium-ion diffusion and charge transfer, and also improve the conversion kinetics of the lithium polysulfides and sulfur. Meanwhile, the formed abundant pores and the added LLZO sheets can respectively increase the physical and chemical adsorption for lithium polysulfides, thus effectively inhibiting the “shuttle effect” [29].

Charge-discharge profiles of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane cells are respectively displayed in Fig. 4d, Fig. S8a and Fig. S8b. As shown in Fig. 4d, at 0.1C the discharge plateaus occur at 2.10 V and 2.30 V, which remain obvious even up to 3C [48]. In contrast, almost no obvious discharge plateaus are observed for the cell assembled with the PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane at high rates in Fig. S8a and Fig. S8b. The potential gaps for the cells assembled with the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane at 0.1C are about 0.14, 0.15 and 0.16 V. The lowest polarization for PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell is attributed to the excellent conductivity of the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite and porous conductive AB coating.

The electrochemical performances of the cells assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1, PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 are displayed in Fig. S9a and b. As the galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles shown in Fig. S9a, two discharge platforms and one charge platform can be observed, corresponding respectively to the reduction peaks and oxidation peak in the CV curves (Fig. 4a). The discharge specific capacities of the cells assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1, PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 at the rate of 0.1C are 1342, 1459 and 1263 mAh/g, respectively. With the increase of LLZO loading rate, the discharge specific capacity of the cells increases first and then decreases, with the highest discharge specific capacity of 1459 mAh/g for PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, probably due to the highest ionic conductivity of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE resulted from the appropriate LLZO loading rate and the porous conductive AB coating, which effectively improves the electronic/ion conductivities and increases the utilization of sulfur. The rate performances of cells assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-1, PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-3 are shown in Fig. S9b. The PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE based cell with an appropriate loading of LLZO sheets exhibits the highest rate performance and highest discharge specific capacities at each rate, probably ascribed to the synergistically increased conductivities and conversion reaction kinetics from LLZO sheets and the porous AB coating.

The electrochemical performances of the cells assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 are compared in Fig. S9c and d. The discharge specific capacity of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell with LLZO sheets (1459 mAh/g) shown in Fig. S9c is much higher than that of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2 cell with LLZO blocks (1146 mAh/g), probably due to the high specific surface area provided by the LLZO sheets, which effectively promotes the Li+ transport and increases the sulfur utilization. Fig. S9d compares the rate performances of cells assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE-2. The PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell with LLZO sheets exhibits higher discharge specific capacities at each rate, ascribed to the high specific surface area of LLZO sheets, the accelerated electronic/ionic transport and the increased conversion reaction kinetics.

The long-cycle properties of the cells assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane are presented in Fig. 4e. The cell assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE shows the discharge capacity retention of 58.9 % after 500 cycles, which is higher than those of the cells assembled with the Celgard membrane (11.8 %) and PEO-PAN CGPE (44.5 %). The coulomb efficiency for the cells assembled with the Celgard membrane and PEO-PAN CGPE greatly fluctuates over the continuous cycling, but the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell shows a high coulombic efficiency (approximately 100 %) and an average decay/cycle of 0.082 % over 500 cycles at 1C. Charge-discharge curves of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane cells at 1C and at different cycles (1, 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 cycles) are shown in Fig. S10. As shown in Fig. S10, the polarization voltage gap of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell is 0.25 V, which is smaller than that of PEO-PAN CGPE (0.30 V) and Celgard membrane (0.41 V), implying the outstanding cyclic stability and reversibility because of the synergistic chemical and physical adsorption of lithium polysulfides and the enhanced redox kinetics offered by the abundant porous structure and the introduction of LLZO sheets and the conductive AB coating. As Table S3 shows, compared to the present membranes, the cell with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE exhibits an excellent electrochemical performance, indicating the obvious advantage in Li-S batteries for high cycle stability and high energy density.

The sulfur to electrolyte ratio (S/E) is an important parameter, a Li-S battery can usually achieve better performance at a lower S/E ratio, and the amount of electrolyte plays a key role in determining the energy density and cost of batteries [49] . The Li-S batteries with high S/E ratios usually show low discharge specific capacity and high polarization, probably due to the spatially uneven electrochemical reaction and reduced utilization of sulfur under the lean-electrolyte condition [50]. In this work, the S/E ratio was controlled at about 0.06 mg μL−1, which is similar or slightly higher compared to some previous reports, for example, 0.025 mg μL−1 of the MOF-PVDF GPE [51] and 0.05 mg μL−1 of the PPZr-GPE [52]. The cell with the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, and further optimization of the composition, structure and properties of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE would bring even higher specific capacity and cyclic stability for high energy density Li-S batteries with high S/E ratio.

The morphology of cycled Li anodes in cells assembled with the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE (Fig. 5 a), PEO-PAN CGPE (Fig. 5c) and Celgard membrane (Fig. 5e) were obtained after 500 cycles (1C). Fig. 5a shows that the quite smooth structure can be observed on the cycled Li anode for the cell assembled with PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, indicating that the uniform and stable SEI film is formed on the Li anode surface, instead of the harmful Li dendrites, which can prevent the anode from corrosion and increase the safety of batteries, [17] as schematically illustrated in Fig. 5h. In sharp contrast, the rough surface with plenty of cracks from the cells assembled with the PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane can be observed obviously in Fig. 5c and Fig. 5e, probably due to the serious corrosion of polysulfides on lithium anode surface derived from the “shuttle effect” [12], and the nonuniform nucleation and growth of the dendrites occur, as demonstrated in Fig. 5g. Fig. 5b, d and f show the related EDS results of the anodes after cycling. The cell assembled with the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE shows the lowest content of sulfur (4.86 %) compared to those of cells assembled with the Celgard membrane (38.32 %) and PEO-PAN CGPE (17.45 %). Fig. S11a-c displays S 2p XPS spectra of the anode in the cycled PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, PEO-PAN CGPE and Celgard membrane cells. Above 165 eV the SO species are observed for all the samples, probably originated from the aerobic oxidation of sulfur species after the cell disassembly. Nearly no signal of the Li2S/Li2S2 at 161–163 eV can be observed on the anode of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE cell [53], implying the successful depression of the shuttle effect from the combined physical and chemical adsorption of lithium polysulfides with the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite layer and the porous AB coating.

The Celgard membrane and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE after adsorption measurement were then etched, and S2p XPS spectra at different depth of the membranes were recorded and displayed respectively in Fig. 6 a and Fig. 6b. Fig. 6a shows core level S2p XPS spectra of Celgard membrane at etch depths of 0, 10 and 50 nm. The relatively weak peaks of Li2S8 located at about 163–165 eV on the surface of Celgard membrane may be due to the weak physical interaction between polysulfides and Celgard membrane [54,55]. The peak strength increases with the etch depth increasing to 10 and 50 nm, which might be attributed to the increased physical adsorption in the interior of porous Celgard membrane. In contrast, at the surface of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE (Fig. 6b), the peaks of Li2S8 become stronger and shift left, probably due to the strong chemical interaction between polysulfides and LLZO in PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE. With the gradual increase of etch depth to 600 nm, the peak intensities become higher and the left shift of peaks becomes more pronounced, indicating the even stronger chemisorption for polysulfides in the interior of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE [56,57]. The peaks at 166–169 eV in Fig. 6b can be attributed to the SO bonds at the surface of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, which are probably originated from the aerobic oxidation of the adsorbed polysulfides [54,55]. With the etch depth increasing, the peak strength of SO bonds decreases gradually, implying the less oxidation of polysulfides in the interior of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrolyte absorbability and suppression of the shuttle effect
ce:section.ce:para: The electrolyte uptake of membranes were measured to evaluate the liquid absorbability and summarized in Table S4. Compared to the Celgard membrane (90.3 %) and PEO-PAN CGPE (133.9 %), the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE displays the electrolyte uptake of up to 202.3 %, which may be due to the combined electrolyte absorbing and storing effects of the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO and the porous AB coating. The high electrolyte uptake is conducive to the rapid migration of Li+ in PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and the physical restriction of the soluble lithium polysulfides [19].

The wettability of the Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN side of PEO-PAN CGPE, PEO-PAN-LLZO side of PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and AB coating are further investigated by the contact angle test and Fig. 6c-f display the corresponding results. When the liquid electrolyte is in contact with Celgard membrane, the PEO-PAN side of the PEO-PAN CGPE, the PEO-PAN-LLZO side of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE and the AB coating, the corresponding contact angles are 43.1°, 18.3°, 14.7° and 20.2°, respectively. The PEO-PAN-LLZO side of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE shows the lowest surface contact angle, indicating the highest wettability and absorption to liquid electrolyte [28], probably due to the composite porous structure with the high-affinity LLZO sheets homogeneously dispersed in polymer matrix (shown in Fig. 1d). These results are consistent with the electrolyte uptake in Table S2. Furthermore, the AB coating displays smaller surface contact angle compared to that of the Celgard membrane, indicating that the AB coating is more favorable to uptake the electrolyte, which might be resulted from the porous structural AB coating (Fig. 1c). The addition of LLZO sheets and the introduction of porous AB coating significantly increase the absorption and storage of electrolyte of the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, which are expected to accelerate the transport of Li+, inhibit the “shuttle effect” and enhance the performance of Li-S battery.

Fig. 7 shows the H-type cell diffusion experiments of the Celgard membrane, PEO-PAN CGPE and PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE after standing for 0, 2 and 8 h. Right side of the cell contains 20 mL DOL/DME solution (1:1), and left side contains 20 mL of Li2S8 solution. The color of H-type cell with Celgard membrane turns yellow on the DOL/DME side after standing for 2 h, then turns dark yellow after standing for 8 h, as shown in Fig. 7a-c. This phenomenen indicates that the Celgard membrane possesses little suppression of lithium polysulfide diffusion. The H-type cell assembled with the PEO-PAN CGPE still keeps clear on the DOL/DME side after standing for 2 h, but turns yellow after standing for 8 h in Fig. 7d-f, indicating that the PEO-PAN CGPE can partly inhibit the polysulfide diffusion, which might be resulted from the limit physical barrier of AB coating and the PEO-PAN composite layer on lithium polysulfides. The H-type cell assembled with the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE still maintains clear on the DOL/DME side after standing for 8 h in Fig. 7g-i, indicating that the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE has a significant inhibitory effect on the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfidethes, which is attributed to both of the physical adsorption capacity offered by the porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite layer and the porous AB coating for lithium multisulfides, and the chemical affinity between lithium polysulfides and the LLZO sheets in the PEO-PAN-LLZO composite.

Compared to the Celgard membrane and PEO-PAN CGPE, the PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE based Li-S batteries demonstrate a significantly improving of rate performance, specific discharge capacity and cyclic stability because of the unique structure and properties of the designed PEO-PAN-LLZO CGPE, as mechanically described in Fig. 8 . The PEO-PAN-LLZO composite gel polymer electrolyte displays a remarkable interface stability with lithium anode, which is beneficial for the uniform Li electroplating/stripping and forming of a stable SEI film. The porous structure provided by the PEO-PAN-LLZO composite can not only absorb and store electrolyte, but also suppress the lithium polysulfide diffusion to the lithium anode. The porous structure and high conductivity offered by the AB coating can not only physically reduce the polysulfide diffusion, but also promote the rapid migration of electrons and enhance the redox kinetics.

In summary, a new type of PEO-PAN -LLZO CGPE was facile prepared by a casting method to effectively inhibit the shuttle effect, increase the utilization of elemental sulfur and protect the lithium anode. The porous PEO-PAN-LLZO composite gel polymer electrolyte can absorb and store electrolyte and suppress the lithium polysulfide diffusion. Meanwhile, the uniform LLZO sheets possess high polysulfide chemical affinity and high conductivity, which can chemically inhibit the “shuttle effect”. The PEO-PAN-LLZO composite displays a remarkable interface stability with lithium anode, which is beneficial for the uniform Li electroplating/ stripping and increase the Li-S battery safety. The porous AB coating can effectively suppress the diffusion of polysulfides, increase the electron transport and enhance the redox kinetics. Under these synergistic effects of the physical adsorption and chemical anchorage, the shuttle effect is successfully depressed and the cell assembled with the PEO-PAN-LLZO GPE demonstrates superior discharge capacity, cyclic capability and rate performance. This work sheds light on the rational designing of composite gel polymer electrolyte towards the high-stability and high-performance Li-S battery application.
